text: this is CJ Cheevers of the New York
Times reporting from Marja Afghanistan
the recent offensive in this Taliban
stronghold meant tough fighting for the
reins of kilo company 3rd battalion 6th
Marines the mission brought lessons and
the ambiguities of guerrilla warfare
after being repeatedly ambushed from the
same set of buildings on the far side of
a canal the company set out before dawn
to clear several compounds from which
the Taliban had been firing three
members of the company had been shot
here the day before one of them died
when third platoons third squad entered
this house they were attacked by a dog
which they killed inside they found seed
and fertilizer piled high typical for a
farmer's house often encounter
insurgency it can be hard to tell what
is what this was an example fertilizer
is part of local life but it can also be
a main ingredient in IEDs or improvised
explosive devices which the Taliban has
left in buildings or on roads and at
canal crossings when the Marines find
IEDs or unexploded ordnance like here
they detonate them back at the compound
the only men there would not talk turn
doors I don't think
the Marines wanted big dogs you a member
of a bomb-making self trained to go mute
but maybe it was simply disabled the
Marines could not tell well I'm the end
get out okay
even with the help of an interpreter and
an Afghan soldier no one was sure who
you was
searches turned up more suspicious items
the man wouldn't claim ownership of a
cell phone or a handful of SIM cards or
electrical cords again these are common
items they can also be assembled into a
bomb remote control devices and a
doorbell kit raised further questions
none of the dozens of homes the Marines
had searched had electricity for that
matter not even after our bills the
Afghan First Sergeant was convinced this
was a bomb makers home let him know we
have enough things here
by the bank material it's very simple
nice guy Jews tell us what he's doing
still the man would not talk was he a
bomb maker or in the wrong place at the
wrong time
the Marines detained him to transfer to
an intelligence team later by this time
he had soiled himself no one was sure
what this meant it could have been fear
but the Marines had also been briefs
that insurgents hoped that feigning
illness or fear might get detainees
medical attention and slow down a patrol
or an interrogation
the Marines began to lead him back to
their outpost the detainee would not
cooperate he dragged his feet then he
collapsed the Afghan First Sergeant
briefly carried him a bit of water got
his attention but still he would not
walk or talk in an already murky fight
it was difficult to say how much of a
threat this man was bringing him back to
the outpost with the Marines at risk
from gunfire in the open fields and also
at risk of further alienating villagers
already distrustful of outsiders the
encounter with the suspected bomb maker
showed that while the means of fighting
were often clear mental else was in the
days ahead the Marines continued their
push sweeping further into territory
that had been slowly under Taliban
control
